unnormalised: **Manufacturing & Supply Chain: Quality Control Concerns Rise in Garment Exports**
normalised: **Manufacturing and Supply Chain: Quality Control Concerns Rise in Garment Exports**

unnormalised: Tirupur, Tamil Nadu - Recent audits have revealed concerns regarding quality control processes within several garment export units in Tirupur. Dr. Meena Iyer, Director of the Apparel Export Promotion Council (AEPC), voiced these concerns following inspections of over 30 manufacturing facilities.
normalised: Tirupur, Tamil Nadu - Recent audits have revealed concerns regarding quality control processes within several garment export units in Tirupur. Doctor Meena Iyer, Director of the A E P C, voiced these concerns following inspections of over thirty manufacturing facilities.

unnormalised: The audits highlighted inconsistencies in fabric sourcing and stitching standards, potentially impacting future orders, especially from European markets. One unit, Sarojini Mills, reported a loss of 20% of their exportable goods due to faulty zippers alone.
normalised: The audits highlighted inconsistencies in fabric sourcing and stitching standards, potentially impacting future orders, especially from European markets. One unit, Sarojini Mills, reported a loss of twenty percent of their exportable goods due to faulty zippers alone.

unnormalised: Industry experts estimate that substandard quality control is costing the Indian garment sector approximately Rs. 500 Crores annually. This comes at a time when competition from Bangladesh and Vietnam is already intense.
normalised: Industry experts estimate that substandard quality control is costing the Indian garment sector approximately rupee five hundred crore annually. This comes at a time when competition from Bangladesh and Vietnam is already intense.

unnormalised: The AEPC is proposing a mandatory skill development program for quality inspectors, focusing on advanced testing techniques and defect identification. This program will be implemented across a 10,000 sq ft training center in the city. Stricter penalties are also being considered for repeated offenders who fail to meet the prescribed quality benchmarks. It aims to ensure 'Shuddh' (pure/perfect) quality for exports, reflecting the 'Make in India' initiative's goals. The program is expected to roll out by Q3 2024.
